summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 regarding the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) litigation efforts to gather documents and information related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes a detailed list of requested records, such as logs, reports, video footage, and correspondence, specifically covering the periods around Epstein's suicide and his removal from suicide watch.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the document; the email chain is focused on gathering all records related to his incarceration, suicide watch, and death at MCC New York.

persons.name: Dr. Miller
persons.context: Mentioned as having forwarded psychology information and being involved in the document gathering process related to Epstein's case.

events.title: Phone call annotation in log book
events.description: An annotation in an Intake Screening log book notes a phone call made by an individual (name redacted) on July 30, 2019.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's death
events.description: The document references the gathering of documents regarding Epstein's suicide, indicating the event occurred around this time (with specific log requests for 8/9-10/2019).

locations: MCC New York, 150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The Bureau of Prisons was actively engaged in litigation and document preservation efforts related to Jeffrey Epstein's death as of May 2020.

A comprehensive list of 20 specific document types was requested, including SHU sign-in logs, visitor logs, meeting records, suicide watch reports, overtime rosters, video footage, and all correspondence with the US Attorney's Office.
Physical log books from the time of the incident and suicide reconstruction had already been turned over to the FBI.
The document indicates an effort to confirm the existence and preservation of the last three phone calls made by Epstein.
The email chain shows coordination between BOP litigation staff and MCC New York personnel to identify appropriate custodians for each requested item.
